title: Authors and Citation
text: Fillmore C, Sprys M, Lythgoe D (2025). cicalc: Calculate Confidence Intervals. R package version 0.1.0.9000, https://gsk-biostatistics.github.io/cicalc/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {cicalc: Calculate Confidence Intervals},   author = {Christina Fillmore and Mike Sprys and Dan Lythgoe},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0.9000},   url = {https://gsk-biostatistics.github.io/cicalc/}, }

title: Calculate Confidence Intervals
text: {cicalc} contains number confidence intervals commonly used pharma industry. full list available methods see package index

title: Calculate Confidence Intervals
text: can install development version cicalc GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("GSK-Biostatistics/cicalc")

title: Calculate Confidence Intervals
text: subsection common CI’s available package :
code: library(cicalc) # Example of CI for proportions x <- c(   TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE,   FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE ) ci_prop_wald(x, conf.level = 0.9) #>  #> ── Wald Confidence Interval without Continuity Correction ────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 90% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2399, 0.7601) ci_prop_wilson(x, correct = TRUE) #>  #> ── Wilson Confidence Interval with continuity correction ─────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2366, 0.7634) ci_prop_clopper_pearson(x) #>  #> ── Clopper-Pearson Confidence Interval ───────────────────────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.1871, 0.8129) ci_prop_agresti_coull(x) #>  #> ── Agresti-Coull Confidence Interval ─────────────────────────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2366, 0.7634) ci_prop_jeffreys(x) #>  #> ── Jeffreys Interval ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2235, 0.7765) # Example of CI for difference of proportions  # Generate binary samples responses <- expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), times = c(10, 10))  # Calculate 95% confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.17, 0.8406)  # Stratified  strat_df <- dplyr::tibble(   responses = expand(c(9, 3, 7, 2), c(10, 10, 10, 10)),   arm = rep(c("treat", "control"), 20),   strata = rep(c("stratum1", "stratum2"), times = c(20, 20)) )  ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata, data = strat_df) #>  #> ── Stratified Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────────────── #> • 12/20 - 9/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 5, stratum2 = 5 #> • Estimate: 0.15 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.1606, 0.4338)

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
text: Calculates Agresti-Coull interval (created Alan Agresti Brent Coull) (95% CI) adding two successes two failures data using Wald formula construct CI.

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
code: ci_prop_agresti_coull(x, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
text: object containing following components: n Number responses N Total number estimate point estimate proportion conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used method Type method used

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
text: $$ \left( \frac{\tilde{p} + z^2_{\alpha/2}/2}{n + z^2_{\alpha/2}} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\tilde{p}(1 - \tilde{p})}{n} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{4n^2}} \right)$$

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
text: Calculates Clopper-Pearson interval calling stats::binom.test(). Also referred exact method.

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
code: ci_prop_clopper_pearson(x, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
text: object containing following components: n Number responses N Total number estimate point estimate proportion conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used method Type method used

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
text: $$ \left( \frac{k}{n} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\frac{k}{n}(1-\frac{k}{n})}{n} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{4n^2}} \right) / \left( 1 + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{n} \right)$$

what: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_ha
title: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_ha
text: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval Difference Proportions

title: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_ha
code: ci_prop_diff_ha(x, by, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_ha
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) (string)  character factor vector exactly two unique levels identifying two groups compare. Can also column name data frame provided data argument. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_ha
text: object containing following components: n number responses group N total number group estimate point estimate difference proportions conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used method Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval

title: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_ha
text: confidence interval given : $$(\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2) \pm \left[ \frac{1}{2 \min(n_1, n_2)} + z \sqrt{ \frac{\hat{p}_1 (1 - \hat{p}_1)}{n_1 - 1} + \frac{\hat{p}_2 (1 - \hat{p}_2)}{n_2 - 1} } \right]$$.

title: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_ha
text: Hauck WW, Anderson S. (1986) comparison large-sample confidence interval methods difference two binomial probabilities American Statistician 40(4). p.318-322. Constructing Confidence Intervals Differences Binomial Proportions SAS

title: Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_ha
code: responses <- expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), times = c(10, 10))  # Calculate 95% confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_ha(x = responses, by = arm) #>  #> ── Anderson-Hauck Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.1922, 1)

what: Haldane Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_haldane
title: Haldane Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_haldane
text: Haldane Confidence Interval Difference Proportions

title: Haldane Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_haldane
code: ci_prop_diff_haldane(x, by, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Haldane Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_haldane
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) (string)  character factor vector exactly two unique levels identifying two groups compare. Can also column name data frame provided data argument. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Haldane Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_haldane
text: object containing following components: n number responses group N total number group estimate point estimate difference proportions (theta*) conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used method Haldane Confidence Interval

title: Haldane Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_haldane
text: confidence interval calculated \(\theta^* \pm w\) : $$\theta^* = \frac{(\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2) + z^2v(1-2\hat{\psi})}{1+z^2u}$$ $$w = \frac{z}{1+z^2u}\sqrt{u\{4\hat{\psi}(1-\hat{\psi})-(\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2)^2\}+2v(1-2\hat{\psi})(\hat{p}_1-\hat{p}_2) +4z^2v^2(1-2\hat{\psi})^2 }$$ $$\hat{\psi} = \frac{\hat{p}_1 + \hat{p}_2}{2}$$ $$u = \frac{1/n_1 + 1/n_2}{4}$$ $$v = \frac{1/n_1 - 1/n_2}{4}$$

title: Haldane Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_haldane
text: Constructing Confidence Intervals Differences Binomial Proportions SAS

title: Haldane Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_haldane
code: responses <- expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), times = c(10, 10))  # Calculate 95% confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_haldane(x = responses, by = arm) #>  #> ── Haldane Confidence Interval ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.503 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.1777, 0.8289)

what: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_jp
title: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_jp
text: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval Difference Proportions

title: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_jp
code: ci_prop_diff_jp(x, by, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_jp
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) (string)  character factor vector exactly two unique levels identifying two groups compare. Can also column name data frame provided data argument. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_jp
text: object containing following components: n number responses group N total number group estimate point estimate difference proportions (theta*) conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used method Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval

title: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_jp
text: confidence interval calculated \(\theta^* \pm w\) : $$\theta^* = \frac{(\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2) + z^2v(1-2\hat{\psi})}{1+z^2u}$$ $$w = \frac{z}{1+z^2u}\sqrt{u\{4\hat{\psi}(1-\hat{\psi})-(\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2)^2\}+2v(1-2\hat{\psi})(\hat{p}_1-\hat{p}_2) +4z^2v^2(1-2\hat{\psi})^2 }$$ $$\hat{\psi} = \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x_1 + 1/2}{n_1+1}+\frac{x_2 + 1/2}{n_2+1}\right)$$ $$u = \frac{1/n_1 + 1/n_2}{4}$$ $$v = \frac{1/n_1 - 1/n_2}{4}$$

title: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_jp
text: Constructing Confidence Intervals Differences Binomial Proportions SAS

title: Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_jp
code: responses <- expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), times = c(10, 10))  # Calculate 95% confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_jp(x = responses, by = arm) #>  #> ── Jeffreys-Perks Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.503 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.176, 0.8306)

what: Mee Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mee
title: Mee Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mee
text: Mee Confidence Interval Difference Proportions

title: Mee Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mee
code: ci_prop_diff_mee(x, by, conf.level = 0.95, delta = NULL, data = NULL)

title: Mee Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mee
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) (string)  character factor vector exactly two unique levels identifying two groups compare. Can also column name data frame provided data argument. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 delta (numeric)  Optionally single number vector numbers -1 1 (inclusive) set difference two groups null hypothesis. provided, function returns test statistic p-value delta hypothesis. data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Mee Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mee
text: object containing following components: n number responses group N total number group estimate point estimate difference proportions (p1-p2) conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used method Mee Confidence Interval

title: Mee Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mee
text: confidence interval calculated \(\theta^* \pm w\) : $$\theta^* = \frac{(\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2) + z^2v(1-2\hat{\psi})}{1+z^2u}$$ $$w = \frac{z}{1+z^2u}\sqrt{u\{4\hat{\psi}(1-\hat{\psi})-(\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2)^2\}+2v(1-2\hat{\psi})(\hat{p}_1-\hat{p}_2) +4z^2v^2(1-2\hat{\psi})^2 }$$ $$\hat{\psi} = \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x_1 + 1/2}{n_1+1}+\frac{x_2 + 1/2}{n_2+1}\right)$$ $$u = \frac{1/n_1 + 1/n_2}{4}$$ $$v = \frac{1/n_1 - 1/n_2}{4}$$

title: Mee Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mee
text: Constructing Confidence Intervals Differences Binomial Proportions SAS

title: Mee Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mee
code: responses <- expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), times = c(10, 10))  # Calculate 95% confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_mee(x = responses, by = arm) #>  #> ── Mee Confidence Interval ───────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.1821, 0.837)

what: Mantel-Haenszel Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_mh_strata
title: Mantel-Haenszel Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_mh_strata
text: Calculates confidence interval Mantel-Haenszel estimate common risk difference across multiple 2x2 tables (strata), using Sato Independent Binomial variance estimator.

title: Mantel-Haenszel Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_mh_strata
code: ci_prop_diff_mh_strata(   x,   by,   strata,   conf.level = 0.95,   sato_var = TRUE,   data = NULL )

title: Mantel-Haenszel Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_mh_strata
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) (string)  character factor vector exactly two unique levels identifying two groups compare. Can also column name data frame provided data argument. strata (numeric)  vector specifying stratum observation. needs length x multiple x multiple levels strata present. Can also column name (vector column names quoted) data frame provided data argument. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 sato_var (logical) Use Sato variance estimate data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Mantel-Haenszel Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_mh_strata
text: object containing following components: estimate Mantel-Haeszel estimated common risk difference conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used variance Variance estimate statistic Z-Statistic null hypothesis, assuming common risk difference 0 p.value p-value null hypothesis, assuming common risk difference 0 method Description method used ("Mantel-Haenszel Confidence Interval, Sato Variance") ("Mantel-Haenszel Confidence Interval, Independent Binomial")

title: Mantel-Haenszel Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_mh_strata
text: Mantel-Haenszel common risk difference computed : $$\hat{\delta}_{MH} = \frac{\sum_{k} w_k \hat{\delta}_k }{\sum_{k} w_k}$$ \(w_k = \frac{n_{xk} n_{yk}}{N_k}\), \(\hat{\delta}_k = s_{xk}/n_{xk} - y_{yk}/n_{yk}\), \(N_k = n_{xk} + n_{yk}\), \(s_{xk}\) \(s_{yk}\) number events group, \(n_{xk}\), \(n_{yk}\) group sizes stratum \(k\). Sato variance : $$\hat{\sigma}^2(\hat{\delta}_{MH}) = \frac{\hat{d}_{MH} \sum_{k}{P_k} + \sum_k Q_k}{\left( \sum_k w_k \right)^2}$$ \(P_k = \frac{n_{xk}^2 s_{yk} - n_{yk}^2 s_{xk} + n_{xk} n_{yk} (n_{yk} - n_{xk})/2}{N_k^2}\) \(Q_k = \frac{s_{xk}(n_{yk} - s_{yk}) + s_{yk}(n_{xk} - s_{xk})}{2 N_k}\). Cochran Independant Binominal variance : $$\hat{\sigma}^2(\hat{\delta}_{C}) = \sum_{k} w_k^2 \left[ \frac{\hat{p}_{1k}(1 - \hat{p}_{1k})}{n_{1k}} + \frac{\hat{p}_{2k}(1 - \hat{p}_{2k})}{n_{2k}} \right]$$ \(\hat{p}_{1k} = \frac{s_{xk}}{n_{xk}}\) \(\hat{p}_{2k} = \frac{s_{yk}}{n_{yk}}\). confidence interval \(\hat{\delta}_{MH} \pm z_{1-\alpha/2} \sqrt{\hat{\sigma}^2(\hat{d}_{MH})}\).

title: Mantel-Haenszel Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_mh_strata
text: Agresti, . (2013). Categorical Data Analysis. 3rd Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Hoboken, NJ p. 231 Cochran, W.G. (1954). Combination estimates different experiments. Biometrics, 10(1), p.101-129

title: Mantel-Haenszel Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_mh_strata
code: # Generate binary samples with strata responses <- expand(c(9, 3, 7, 2), c(10, 10, 10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), 20) strata <- rep(c("stratum1", "stratum2"), times = c(20, 20))  # Calculate common risk difference ci_prop_diff_mh_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata) #>  #> ── Mantel-Haenszel Risk Difference Confidence Interval, Sato Variance ────────── #> • 12/20 - 9/20 #> • Estimate: 0.15 #> • Variance: 0.024 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.1528, 0.4528) # Calculate risk difference with independent binomial variance ci_prop_diff_mh_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata, sato_var = FALSE) #>  #> ── Mantel-Haenszel Risk Difference Confidence Interval, Independent Binomial ─── #> • 12/20 - 9/20 #> • Estimate: 0.15 #> • Variance: 0.024 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.1521, 0.4521)

what: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
text: Calculates Miettinen-Nurminen (MN) confidence interval difference two proportions. method can accurate traditional methods, especially small sample sizes proportions close 0 1.

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
text: function implements Miettinen-Nurminen method compute confidence intervals difference two proportions. approach: Calculates Miettinen-Nurminen score test statistic different possible values proportion difference (delta) Identifies delta values test statistic equals critical value corresponding desired confidence level Returns boundary values confidence interval limits method uses score test small-sample correction factor, making accurate normal approximation methods, especially small samples extreme proportions. equation test statistics follows: $$H_0: \hat{d}-\delta <= 0 \qquad \text{vs.} \qquad H_1: \hat{d}-\delta > 0$$ $$ T_\delta = \frac{\hat{p_x} - \hat{p_y} - \delta}{\sigma_{mn}(\delta)}$$ \(\hat{p_*} = s_*/n_*\) represent observed number successes divided number participant group. \(\sigma_{mn}(\delta)\) function delta values create following equation" \(\tilde{p_*}\) represent MLE proportions. $$ \sigma_{mn}(\delta) = \sqrt{\left[\frac{\tilde{p_y}(1-\tilde{p_y})}{n_x}+\frac{\tilde{p_x}(1-\tilde{p_x})}{n_y} \right]\left(\frac{N}{N-1}\right)} $$ \( \tilde{p_x} = 2p\cdot{cos()} - \frac{L_2}{3L_3}\) \( \tilde{p_y} = \tilde{p_x} + \delta\) : \(p = \pm \sqrt{\frac{L_2^2}{(3L_3)^2} - \frac{L_1}{3L_3}}\) \(= 1/3[\pi + cos^{-1}(q/p^3)]\) \(q = \frac{L_2^3}{(3L_3)^3} - \frac{L_1L_2}{6L_3^2} + \frac{L_0}{2L_3}\) \(L_3 = n_x + n_y \) \(L_2 = (n_x + 2 n_y)\delta - N - (s_x + s_y)\) \(L_1 = (n_y\delta - L_3 - 2s_y)\delta + s_x + s_y\) \(L_0 = s_y\delta(1-\delta)\) information equations see Miettinen (1985)

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
text: Miettinen, O. S., & Nurminen, M. (1985). Comparative analysis two rates. Statistics Medicine, 4(2), 213-226.

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
code: # Generate binary samples responses <- expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), times = c(10, 10))  # Calculate 95% confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.17, 0.8406)  # Calculate 99% confidence interval ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm, conf.level = 0.99) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.6 #> • 99% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.0218, 0.8792)  # Calculate the p-value under the null hypothesis delta = -0.1 ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm, delta = -0.1) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.17, 0.8406) #>  #> ── Delta  #> • At -0.1 the statistic is 3.115 and the p-value is 9e-04  # Calculate from a data.frame data <- data.frame(responses, arm) ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm, data = data) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 9/10 - 3/10 #> • Estimate: 0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.17, 0.8406)

text: object containing following components: estimate point estimate difference proportions (p_x - p_y) conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used delta delta value(s) used statistic Z-Statistic null hypothesis based given 'delta' p.value p-value null hypothesis based given 'delta' method Description method used ("Stratified {method} Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval") delta provided statistic p.value NULL

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
text: function implements stratified Miettinen-Nurminen method compute confidence intervals difference two proportions across multiple strata. $$H_0: \hat{d}-\delta <= 0 \qquad \text{vs.} \qquad H_1: \hat{d}-\delta > 0$$ "score" method weighted MN score first described original 1985 paper. formula : Calculates weights stratum \(w_i = \frac{n_{xi} \cdot n_{yi}}{n_{xi} + n_{yi}}\) Computes overall weighted difference \(\hat{d} = \frac{\sum w_i \hat{p}_{xi}}{\sum w_i} -           \frac{\sum w_i \hat{p}_{yi}}{\sum w_i}\) Uses stratified test statistic: $$Z_{\delta} = \frac{\hat{d} - \delta}           {\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^k \left(\frac{w_i}{\sum w_i}\right)^2 \cdot \hat{\sigma}_{mn}^2({d})}}$$ Finds range values \(\delta\) stratified test statistic (\(Z_\delta\)) falls acceptance region \(\{ Z_\delta < z_{\alpha/2}\}\) \(\hat{\sigma}_{mn}^2(\hat{d})\) Miettinen-Nurminen variance estimate. See details ci_prop_diff_mn() \(\hat{\sigma}_{mn}^2(\delta)\) calculated. "summary score" method follows meta-analyses proposed Agresti 2013 consistent "Summary Score Confidence Limits" method used SAS. formula : point estimate stratified risk difference weighted average midpoints within-stratum MN confidence intervals: $$       \hat{d}_{\text{S}} = \sum_i \hat{d}_i w_i       $$ Define \(s_i\) width CI \(\)th stratum divided \(2 \times z_{\alpha/2}\) stratum weights given $$     w_i = \left( \frac{1}{s_i^2} \right) \bigg/ \sum_i \left( \frac{1}{s_i^2} \right)     $$ variance \(\hat{d}_{\text{S}} \) computed $$      \widehat{\text{Var}}(\hat{d}_{\text{S}}) = \frac{1}{\sum_i \left( \frac{1}{s_i^2} \right) }     $$ Confidence limits stratified risk difference estimate $$     \hat{d}_{\text{S}} \pm \left( z_{\alpha /2} \times \widehat{\text{Var}}(\hat{d}_{\text{S}}) \right)     $$

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
text: Miettinen, O. S., & Nurminen, M. (1985). Comparative analysis two rates. Statistics Medicine, 4(2), 213-226. Common Risk Difference :: Base SAS(R) 9.4 Procedures Guide: Statistical Procedures, Third Edition Agresti, . (2013). Categorical Data Analysis. 3rd Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Hoboken, NJ

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
code: # Generate binary samples with strata responses <- expand(c(9, 3, 7, 2), c(10, 10, 10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), 20) strata <- rep(c("stratum1", "stratum2"), times = c(20, 20))  # Calculate stratified confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata) #>  #> ── Stratified Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────────────── #> • 12/20 - 9/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 5, stratum2 = 5 #> • Estimate: 0.15 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.1606, 0.4338)  # Using the summary score method ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata,                       method = "summary score") #>  #> ── Stratified Summary Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────── #> • 12/20 - 9/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 0.511, stratum2 = 0.489 #> • Estimate: -0.126 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.4113, 0.1586)  # Calculate 99% confidence interval ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata,                       conf.level = 0.99) #>  #> ── Stratified Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────────────── #> • 12/20 - 9/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 5, stratum2 = 5 #> • Estimate: 0.15 #> • 99% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.2509, 0.5072)  # Calculate p-value under null hypothesis delta = 0.2 ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata,                       delta = 0.2) #>  #> ── Stratified Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────────────── #> • 12/20 - 9/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 5, stratum2 = 5 #> • Estimate: 0.15 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.1606, 0.4338) #>  #> ── Delta  #> • At 0.2 the statistic is -0.319 and the p-value is 0.375

title: Newcombe Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_nc
text: Wilson (Score) confidence limits without continuity correction individual binomial proportion, \(p_i = x_i / n_i\), \(= 1, 2\), given : $$ \frac{   (2 n_i \hat{p}_i + z^2)   \pm   z \sqrt{ 4 n_i \hat{p}_i (1 - \hat{p}_i) + z^2 } }{   2 (n_i + z^2) } $$ Denote lower upper Wilson (Score) confidence limits \(p_i\) \(L_i\) \(U_i\), respectively. , Newcombe (Score) confidence limits difference proportions (\(p_1 - p_2\)) given : $$ \text{Lower limit: } (\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2) - \sqrt{ (\hat{p}_1 - L_1)^2 + (U_2 - \hat{p}_2)^2 } $$ $$ \text{Upper limit: } (\hat{p}_1 - \hat{p}_2) + \sqrt{ (U_1 - \hat{p}_1)^2 + (\hat{p}_2 - L_2)^2 } $$ confidence intervals continuity correction individual binomial proportion obtained using Wilson (Score) confidence limits continuity correction. binomial proportion \(p_i = x_i / n_i\), \(= 1, 2\), confidence intervals given : $$ \frac{ 2 n_i \hat{p}_i + z^2 }{ 2 (n_i + z^2) } \; \pm \; \frac{ z }{ 2 (n_i + z^2) } \sqrt{   z^2 - \frac{2}{n_i} + 4 \hat{p}_i   \left[ n_i (1 - \hat{p}_i) + 1 \right] } $$

title: Newcombe Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_nc
text: Newcombe, R. G. (1998). Interval estimation difference independent proportions: Comparison eleven methods. Statistics Medicine, 17(8), 873–890. Constructing Confidence Intervals Differences Binomial Proportions SAS

title: Stratified Newcombe Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_nc_strata
text: $$ L = \hat{d}_{\rm MH} - z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{   \sum_h w_h^2 L_{2h} (1 - L_{2h}) +   \sum_h w_h^2 U_{1h} (1 - U_{1h}) } $$ $$ U = \hat{d}_{\rm MH} + z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{   \sum_h w_h^2 L_{2h} (1 - L_{2h}) +   \sum_h w_h^2 U_{1h} (1 - U_{1h}) } $$ : \(\hat{d}_{\rm MH}\): Mantel-Haenszel common risk difference \(z_{\alpha/2}\): standard normal critical value \(w_h\): stratum weights \(L_{2h}\), \(U_{1h}\): Wilson-type CI limits stratum h

title: Stratified Newcombe Common Risk Difference Confidence Interval — ci_prop_diff_nc_strata
code: set.seed(1) rsp <- sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), 100, TRUE) grp <- sample(c("Placebo", "Treatment"), 100, TRUE) strata_data <- data.frame(   "f1" = sample(c("a", "b"), 100, TRUE),   "f2" = sample(c("x", "y", "z"), 100, TRUE),   stringsAsFactors = TRUE ) strata <- interaction(strata_data)  ci_prop_diff_nc_strata(   x = rsp, by = grp, strata = strata, weights_method = "cmh",   conf.level = 0.95 ) #>  #> ── Stratified Newcombe Confidence Interval without continuity correction, CMH ── #> • 49 responses out of 100 #> • Weights: a.x = 0.122, b.x = 0.273, a.y = 0.132, b.y = 0.14, a.z = 0.193, b.z #> = 0.14 #> • Estimate: 0.042 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.1508, 0.2314)

title: Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson
text: $$\frac{\hat{p} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{2n} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1 - \hat{p})}{n} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{4n^2}}}{1 + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{n}}$$

text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) strata (numeric)  vector specifying stratum observation. needs length x multiple x multiple levels strata present. Can also column name (vector column names quoted) data frame provided data argument. weights (numeric) weights level strata. NULL, estimated using iterative algorithm minimizes weighted squared length confidence interval. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 max.iterations (positive integer) maximum number iterations iterative procedure used find estimates optimal weights. correct (scalar logical) include continuity correction. information, see example stats::prop.test(). data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Stratified Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson_strata

title: Stratified Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson_strata
text: $$\frac{\hat{p}_j + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{2n_j} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}_j(1 - \hat{p}_j)}{n_j} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{4n_j^2}}}{1 + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{n_j}}$$

title: Stratified Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson_strata
code: # Stratified Wilson confidence interval with unequal probabilities  set.seed(1) rsp <- sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), 100, TRUE) strata_data <- data.frame(   "f1" = sample(c("a", "b"), 100, TRUE),   "f2" = sample(c("x", "y", "z"), 100, TRUE),   stringsAsFactors = TRUE ) strata <- interaction(strata_data) n_strata <- ncol(table(rsp, strata)) # Number of strata  ci_prop_wilson_strata(   x = rsp, strata = strata,   conf.level = 0.90 ) #>  #> ── Stratified Wilson Confidence Interval without continuity correction ───────── #> • 49 responses out of 100 #> • Weights: a.x = 0.207, b.x = 0.178, a.y = 0.192, b.y = 0.16, a.z = 0.135, b.z #> = 0.128 #> • Estimate: 0.49 #> • 90% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.4073, 0.5648)  # Not automatic setting of weights ci_prop_wilson_strata(   x = rsp, strata = strata,   weights = rep(1 / n_strata, n_strata),   conf.level = 0.90 ) #>  #> ── Stratified Wilson Confidence Interval without continuity correction ───────── #> • 49 responses out of 100 #> • Weights: 0.167, 0.167, 0.167, 0.167, 0.167, 0.167 #> • Estimate: 0.49 #> • 90% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.419, 0.579)

what: Mantel-Haenszel Stratified Relative Risk Confidence Interval — ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata
title: Mantel-Haenszel Stratified Relative Risk Confidence Interval — ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata
text: Calculates confidence interval Mantel-Haenszel estimate common relative risk across multiple 2x2 tables (strata)

title: Mantel-Haenszel Stratified Relative Risk Confidence Interval — ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata
code: ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata(x, by, strata, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Mantel-Haenszel Stratified Relative Risk Confidence Interval — ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) (string)  character factor vector exactly two unique levels identifying two groups compare. Can also column name data frame provided data argument. strata (numeric)  vector specifying stratum observation. needs length x multiple x multiple levels strata present. Can also column name (vector column names quoted) data frame provided data argument. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Mantel-Haenszel Stratified Relative Risk Confidence Interval — ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata
text: object containing following components: estimate Mantel-Haeszel estimated common risk difference conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used variance Mantel-Haenszel variance estimate \(Var(log(RR_MH))\) method Description method used ("Mantel-Haenszel Common Relative Risk Confidence Interval")

title: Mantel-Haenszel Stratified Relative Risk Confidence Interval — ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata
text: Mantel-Haenszel relative risk difference computed : $$RR_{MH} = \frac{\sum_{k} s_{xk}~n_{yk}/N_k}{\sum_{k} s_{yk}~n_{xk}/N_k}$$ variance : $$\hat{\sigma}^2 = \hat{Var}(log(RR_{MH})) = \frac{\sum_{k}(n_{xk}~n_{yk}~(s_{xk}+s_{yk}) - s_{xk}~s_{yk}~N_k)/N_k^2} {(\sum_{k}s_{xk}~n_{yk}/N_k)(\sum_{k}s_{yk}~n_{xk}/N_k)}$$ confidence interval \(\left(RR_{MH}\times exp(-z_{1-\alpha/2} \sqrt{\hat{\sigma}^2}, RR_{MH}\times exp(z_{1-\alpha/2} \sqrt{\hat{\sigma}^2}\right)\).

title: Mantel-Haenszel Stratified Relative Risk Confidence Interval — ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata
text: Agresti, . (2013). Categorical Data Analysis. 3rd Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Hoboken, NJ

title: Mantel-Haenszel Stratified Relative Risk Confidence Interval — ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata
code: # Generate binary samples with strata responses <- expand(c(9, 3, 7, 2), c(10, 10, 10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), 20) strata <- rep(c("stratum1", "stratum2"), times = c(20, 20))  # Calculate common risk difference ci_rel_risk_cmh_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata) #>  #> ── Mantel-Haenszel Common Relattive Risk Confidence Interval ─────────────────── #> • 12/20 - 9/20 #> • Estimate: 1.333 #> • Variance: 0.093 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.7344, 2.4208)

what: Function to combine strata via interaction if strata is passed as a vector — combine_strata
title: Function to combine strata via interaction if strata is passed as a vector — combine_strata
text: Function combine strata via interaction strata passed vector

title: Function to combine strata via interaction if strata is passed as a vector — combine_strata
code: combine_strata(x, strata)

what: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
text: Converts count data (number successes total sample size) binary vector TRUE/FALSE values. useful converting summary statistics back raw data format analysis functions require individual-level data.

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
code: expand(x, n)

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
text: x Integer (vector integers) representing number successes. n Integer (vector integers) representing total number participants.

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
text: logical vector TRUE represents success FALSE represents failure. length vector equals sum sample sizes.

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
text: pair values x n, function creates vector x TRUE values followed n-x FALSE values. multiple pairs provided, resulting vectors concatenated order.

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
code: # Convert 4 successes out of 13 participants to binary data expand(4, 13) #>  [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #> [13] FALSE  # Convert multiple groups of data # Group 1: 9 successes out of 10 # Group 2: 3 successes out of 10 expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) #>  [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE #> [13]  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE

what: To get the n's and response totals with out without strata — get_counts
title: To get the n's and response totals with out without strata — get_counts
text: get n's response totals without strata

title: To get the n's and response totals with out without strata — get_counts
code: get_counts(x, by, strata = 1)
